title: 108_hr3137
content: SECTION 1. FINDINGS. Congress finds that Saudi Arabia is the center of Wahabbism, funding Hamas and supporting Palestinian terrorist groups, overseen by Prince Nayef bin Abdel Aziz. A Saudi telethon raised $112 million for Al Quds, with the Saudi government providing cash payments to families of "martyrs." A senior Saudi official criticized Jews for manipulating media and world organizations. United States Armed Forces found concerning materials in the office of the Saudi High Commission in Sarajevo. In Sarajevo, documents found in the office of the Saudi High Commission revealed Saudi funding for Hamas to develop a missile. In San Diego in 2000, a Saudi intelligence agent assisted two individuals who later hijacked planes on 9/11. Princess Haifa al-Faisal, wife of the Saudi Ambassador to the US, transferred $15,000 in 1998. Princess Haifa al-Faisal transferred $15,000 in 1998 and $2,000 monthly to Osama Bassnan, a Saudi resident of San Diego. Bassnan, with Saudi financial support, aided individuals involved in the 9/11 attacks. The Saudi government initially refused to freeze Osama bin Laden's assets post-9/11. Saudi Arabia hindered FBI investigators from interviewing witnesses or suspects. The Government of Saudi Arabia obstructed US efforts to apprehend terrorists responsible for attacks on US military installations, including the bombing of Khobar Towers in 1996 and the Marine barracks in Beirut in 1983. Saudi officials also hindered FBI investigations into individuals involved in the 9/11 attacks. During the first Gulf War, Saudi officials refused to allow US troops to hold Christmas services on Saudi territory, despite US protection from Iraqi invasion. Prohibition against direct funding for certain countries: No funds from foreign operations appropriations can be used to finance assistance or reparations to Cuba, Libya, North Korea, Iran, Saudi Arabia, or Syria, including loans, credits, insurance, and guarantees from the Export-Import Bank of the United States.
